item.source: Video of srt8 getting hit from behind

item.title: Video of srt8 getting hit from behind
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

[quote=“The Wanderer, post:27, topic:390649”]The bodies of cars used to be made of out hard, rigid steel and when impacted, all of the force would be transfered to the passengers causing whiplash and other related injuries. Then car companies created what is called the crumple zone and the rigid passenger cell. The crumple zone is that part of the car that is intended to crumple up and absorb most of the impact, acting as a cushion. The rigid passenger cell is the area where people inside of the car are seated. You would still want this “box” to be made out of hard, rigid steel, obviously. If it were to crumple as the front and rear of a car is designed to, the passengers would be most likely killed. Here’s a diagram for you people that are more visual learners.

I remember learning all of this in Driver’s Ed haha. The rear end of that car crumpled up, because it was hit by a large truck traveling at a decent speed.[/quote]
buffer zone

Read full topic

item.source: Video of srt8 getting hit from behind

item.title: Video of srt8 getting hit from behind
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

The bodies of cars used to be made of out hard, rigid steel and when impacted, all of the force would be transfered to the passengers causing whiplash and other related injuries. Then car companies created what is called the crumple zone and the rigid passenger cell. The crumple zone is that part of the car that is intended to crumple up and absorb most of the impact, acting as a cushion. The rigid passenger cell is the area where people inside of the car are seated. You would still want this “box” to be made out of hard, rigid steel, obviously. If it were to crumple as the front and rear of a car is designed to, the passengers would be most likely killed. Here’s a diagram for you people that are more visual learners.

I remember learning all of this in Driver’s Ed haha. The rear end of that car crumpled up, because it was hit by a large truck traveling at a decent speed.

Read full topic

Do you understand physics at all?

item.title: Video of srt8 getting hit from behind
item.dc:creator: @chrisn2323 chrisn2323
item.description:
@chrisn2323 wrote:

Thug-life:

There are certainly much more plastic used in all cars today than there was, but I have never seen a car here (We don’t get many American cars here (We get European manufactured and designed American cars, like some of the Fords), but I’ve never seen one of these react in such a way to being hit. The body on that srt8 is truly horrible.

bumpers are designed to crumple to absorb the impact and minimize injury to the passangers. All modern cars are like this.

Read full topic

item.title: Video of srt8 getting hit from behind
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Thug-life:

There are certainly much more plastic used in all cars today than there was, but I have never seen a car here (We don’t get many American cars here (We get European manufactured and designed American cars, like some of the Fords), but I’ve never seen one of these react in such a way to being hit. The body on that srt8 is truly horrible.

Maybe you don’t still have trucks with solid steel chrome bumpers over there like the one that hit this car pretty hard?

It looked like to me the bumper needed replaced, and I can’t tell if the tail lights needed replaced or not as well. And any ‘plastic’ car would suffer that damage from a rear end collision like this.

Read full topic
